title: 111_hr4850
content: The Act titled "American Job Creation and Investment Act" allows for the temporary utilization of unused AMT credits based on domestic wages and investment. The "American Job Creation and Investment Act" allows corporations to elect an increase in the limitation imposed by subsection (c) for taxable years by the AMT credit adjustment amount, which is the lesser of a corporation's minimum tax credit or 20 percent of new qualifying domestic wages. The "American Job Creation and Investment Act" allows corporations to increase the limitation for taxable years by the AMT credit adjustment amount, which is based on new qualifying domestic compensation and investments. Qualifying domestic compensation includes 20% of new wages paid during the taxable year, 20% of new domestic investments, and 10% of qualifying wages paid in the previous year. The curr_chunk discusses the definition of "new qualifying domestic compensation" and "new domestic investments" for the purposes of the American Job Creation and Investment Act. It specifies that new qualifying domestic compensation refers to payments made for the employment of individuals hired during the taxable year, while new domestic investments refer to the cost of investments made domestically. The curr_chunk defines "new domestic investments" as the cost of qualified property placed in service in the US by the taxpayer during the taxable year. It also includes a special maintenance of workforce rule for taxable years beginning in 2011. The curr_chunk discusses rules for adjusting compensation for acquisitions and dispositions in a trade or business, as well as the refundable nature of the credit increase resulting from these adjustments. An election under this subsection must be made at a specified time. The curr_chunk discusses the process for making an election to increase the limitation under subsection (c) for a corporation's taxable year including December 31, 2009. The election must be made at a specified time and can only be revoked with the consent of the Secretary. Until a manner for making the election is prescribed, a taxpayer can provide written notification to the Secretary and the Commissioner of Internal Revenue to be treated as having made a valid election. The election to increase the limitation under subsection (c) for a corporation's taxable year must not exceed the AMT credit adjustment amount as of the election date. Any adjustment amount not included in the election will be included in the corporation's return for the first taxable year after December 31, 2009. The election is irrevocable and can only be made if the corporation files necessary amended returns to comply with paragraph (11). An aggregation rule applies to affiliated group corporations filing a consolidated tax return. The election allows a corporation to increase the limitation under subsection (c) for its taxable year, not exceeding the AMT credit adjustment amount as of the election date. The election is irrevocable and requires filing necessary amended returns. An aggregation rule applies to affiliated group corporations filing a consolidated tax return. Partnerships with over 50% ownership by the corporation are treated as a single entity for tax purposes. The partnership's new domestic investments for the taxable year will be determined by the Secretary. Any taxpayer who previously made an election under section 172(b)(1)(H) will be deemed to have revoked it by making their first election under this subsection. The Secretary may issue regulations to prevent fraud and abuse. This subsection will not apply to taxable years starting after December 31, 2011. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to allow for a quick refund of refundable credits. The effective date for these amendments varies depending on the taxable year.
